replies.author: @mybedisgareth
replies.text:
@Porter_992 Usually it is though. 
Why are they regretting it? Were they drunk or on drugs to the point where it affects communication or inhibitions? Were they lied to in order to trick them into sex? Did things go further than they agreed/wanted to (like the example in this video)? Did they feel there was some kind of consequence for saying no beyond not having sex? Did they want things to stop at some point and things didn't?
If the answer to any of those questions is yes, then it is rape or SA.
And even when it's not non-consensual, if your sexual partners regret being sexual with you, some self-reflection is definitely called for.

replies.text: The real problem is that consent isn't romantic. Romance is basically about telepathy - it's the fantasy of a partner who just naturally and effortlessly is and does exactly what you want. Someone who doesn't need to ask what you want because they already know and always act in accordance with it. Obviously, that doesn't exist in the real world and never will, and we should all want clear communications in our real relationships. But even those of us who know that will still dream of romance that doesn't require it, and that psychic romance is what media depicts, because when you tell a story about a healthy relationship, it's dull.

replies.author: @memegazer
replies.text:
I don't like the term "rape culture"

bc it implies that no efforts at all are made to define and legally penalyze rape

Ideally you should presume innocence in any alleged crime not just rape

and one should not confuse the difficulties in defining rape and then varifying it beyond reasonable doubt as a criminal act is the same as a systemic tolerance of rape

the issue is hypothetically easy to solve by simply requiring a legal binding record that both parties sing or verbally agree to for consent

but the nature of human sexuality would make such things seem like "mood killers"

The term "rape culture" imo runs up against how gender roles themselves, in a sexual context, are objectified

the feminin and the masculine, the pursuer and pursuee, the sub and the dom...etc

I don't think the issue is that a society tacitly endorses rape or that it enables a culture that normalizes rape

rather that a society does not communicate honestly about sexuality in a general public way or in individual interactions

sex is itself a subject of taboo, and sexuality education and policy is in conflict with privacy and agency in the context of social norms surrounding role expectations

replies.author: @memegazer
replies.text:
One would think that more women would proactively or were at least open to explicit legally binding documentation of consent

considering that they are more socially conditioned and perhaps even naturally inclined to think about the consequences of sex than men are conditioned or feel naturally obligated

but I find that while women are readily willing to point out the failures of "rape culture"

They are less willing to take an active role in calling it out with their own agency affriming consent signaling


and say that as a cis het person

but I suspect that this is true on the level of non cis and non het social and individual dynamics as well

replies.author: @Anngrl69
replies.text:
Appreciate your comment! We do have to be nuanced and both men and women should take accountability for their ability to communicate and facilitate a conversation about consent. 

I have always been a woman who is interested and likes sex. When I was in college I was at a party where a cute guy was chatting with me at a table game and very lightly putting his hand on my back. I was shy and insecure so I didn‚Äôt give him any signs that I liked his actions and he pretty quickly left me alone. 

Afterwards, I felt regret about the situation because I would‚Äôve been down to be freaky lol. Part of me thought, if only he would‚Äôve been more insistent. Looking back 6 years later, I realize I actually have regret for not being able to communicate and show what I wanted. I also know myself at that time would not have the self esteem to be direct like that because I had the idea that I shouldn‚Äôt be apparent about my desires or vocalize them because that would make me less demure and therefore less desirable and respectable. 

There was a lot of detangling and self growth to be had, and I am happy to say I have done so much since then. A year after that experience, I started learning about the kink community and got educated on consent, preferences, boundaries, etc. I feel very blessed to not have an experience where I wonder if I was coerced into sex. I‚Äôve had pity sex, lame sex, and unsatisfying sex, but all of it was consensual and taught me a little more about what I did want. 

If we want men to obtain consent, women also need to be able to vocalize what we want instead of hoping a man reads us correctly and makes the ‚Äúright‚Äù choice. The boy in college who backed off when I didn‚Äôt give him any positive signs gained a lot of respect from me, and that probably made me regret not hooking up with him even more lol. Men who respect women are the most attractive. 

Edit: Oops I realized pity sex could be viewed as coercion, so I want to clarify that the guy did not pressure me. I knew he was into me and I thought he had a great personality but I wasn‚Äôt attracted to him. I was horny and thought sex may be enjoyable and it was clear he wanted to have sex if I was down. It was not enjoyable and I regretted not being up front about my lack of attraction cause I led him on and he was excited for a second date that I had to shut down. He was probably confused why I went that far when I wasn‚Äôt interested and I would never want someone to do the same to me. No more pity sex, it‚Äôs always a mistake.

replies.text: I agree. You could really see when this case was in the public eye how allergic everyone was to viewing it as a teachable moment. replies.author: @jimjo8541
replies.text:
@DaniCarrieyou can be a victim but also be partially responsible for what happens to you. I‚Äôm not talking about wearing a mini skirt or anything of that nature. I‚Äôm talking about letting a pattern of non consensual behavior happen without you taking any action to remove yourself from the situation. This is a grown ass person. It‚Äôs not a vulnerable child. They weren‚Äôt restrained  in any way or threatened with harm.
Also, maybe don‚Äôt go back to a guy‚Äôs place on the first date unless you‚Äôre planning to go all the way?  I‚Äôm not saying he‚Äôs entitled to do whatever he wants in this situation. Of course he‚Äôs not. You can be married for 20 years and that doesn‚Äôt mean your partner can do whatever they want. But you are making yourself EXTREMELY vulnerable in a situation with a stranger. You don‚Äôt know how this person operates behind closed doors. 

I will say I do lean more toward victim blaming in a lot of situations. Not necessarily when it comes to this topic but let‚Äôs say someone decides to go camping out in the middle of the woods- alone- and they wind up going missing.  Should they be allowed to go camping and return home, just fine?  Or course!  But are there many dangers in such an active?  Yes!  And are you taking enough precautions to ensure your safety if you go camping alone in the middle of the woods, with just a flashlight as your protection?  No!  

So many things can go wrong in even safe situations. Why risk it in situations that you‚Äôve been constantly told are dicey??  You all just said you‚Äôd choose A BEAR over a man. Yet, you‚Äôre going to ASSUME a stranger/man is going to respect your consent?  Your boundaries??

author: @kaymitchell6143
text:
Literally. I will tell my mama‚Äôs story till the day I die. My mama was in undergrad living her life as an honors student and a campus socialite. 

She had one man walk up on her and corner her because he wanted to date her and she rejected him. Luckily in that situation she was able to fight him off. People were there but did not say anything and just laughed at the guy that he was ‚Äúbeat up by a girl.‚Äù

Another time, her and her friends all went to a hangout spot (after a party) where she ended up alone in a room with the man who raped her. She was screaming and crying all the while her ‚Äúfriends‚Äù were in the other room and could hear what happened. When she busted out of the room frantic they convinced her not to report him because they didn‚Äôt want her to ‚Äúruin a Black man‚Äôs future.‚Äù 

We do not take rape serious and when the accused is someone we know we take it personal instead of defending the victim. It causes too much harm and stress on the victims. My mom is in her 50s and still has self image issues because of what happened and how she was treated in these situations. 

And the sad part is I can pretty much say the same thing for my best friend and my partner who have experienced sexual assaults as children.

author: @tariqdanzig3621
text: 20-something year old cis male here. My mom told me of an experience she had when her uncle acted toward her in a physically inappropriate way. They were at the dinner table with everyone in the immediate family there and totally aware of what had just happened. No one did anything. I had a girlfriend in high school who broke into tears as we were walking up the stairs to our first class, sobbing that she had been raped. I think at least 2 or 3 other girls i have dated or spoken to have confided in me that they have gone through some form of assault or abuse. It was shocking as a teenager and its horribly, frustratingly, disappointingly mundane now. Neil Gaiman was someone i respected and enjoyed quite a bit, and when the allegations came out, i barely reacted. Its just so normal. This stuff is immensely widespread and one of my greatest fears is that I may, even unintentionally, make a woman feel this way in my lifetime. Support the women and girls in your life. Much love, stay safe. Thanks for this video, Olurinatti!

author: @WarmNaturalLite
text:
As a man, i have been Grace too.  
It's taken me years of therapy to be able to name all of the sexual encounters that i didn't want to have or was coerced into.  You don't understand the bomb that goes off when you say "no" to a woman, especially when they are  risking their conditioning and being vulnerable enough to instigate.  I've had my manhood called into question, i've been accused of preferring children to "real women,"  I've had horrible rumors spread and harmful actions taken against me.  

I have had doors locked behind me.   

The lesson that we are all taught is this:
 "You can't say no. No means nothing to anyone, and you will be punished for even uttering it."   

And that is something that we ALL need to unlearn.   ALL OF US.   This is patriarchy maneuvering behind the veil. This is how we are, as you point out, CONDITIONED to be.  That conditioning has a ton of violence behind it, implied but also very real.  
We are forced at gunpoint to learn to harm each other, so that we do not collectivize and step into the power of our communities. 


I'm rooting for all of us, but i plan on fighting too. Thank you for your heartfelt work, always <3

replies.author: @nedisahonkey
replies.text: @b6d-o9r I assume it would be some sort of ethics thing you agreed to upon enrollment to always receive affirmative consent if you chose to have sex with someone from the college or while at college. I had to take a very boilerplate online test on rudimentary sexual ethics for my college

replies.author: @Outsideaire
replies.text: It meant that as a participant in sexual activities you had to both obtain and give verbal affirmative consent for each and every sexual act  engaged in.

replies.author: @jfm14
replies.text:
‚Äã@b6d-o9r My understanding of affirmative consent is that in order for a sexual encounter to be considered consensual, there needs to be an explicit "yes" rather than just the absence of a "no". The idea is to encourage people to clearly communicate their desires and not merely make assumptions about what the other person wants... because nonverbal cues like body language can be easily misinterpreted and sometimes people want to stop, but struggle to communicate that for any number of reasons (e.g. trauma, social anxiety, passivity, etc.)

I'm not sure, but I assume the college added this to their code of conduct. I believe most (if not all) higher ed institutions in the US have a code of conduct, which students must agree to abide by in order to enroll/attend.

author: @hannaheldredge5738
text:
I've worked with SA/DV survivors for a decent amount of time now and one of the more heartbreaking thoughts I see come out of MOST survivors is that they "don't feel like it was 'bad' enough", like we compare what happened to us so much to things that we were told and shown as sexual violence through media and peers that if a survivor didn't literally get kidnapped and held at gunpoint then their experience isn't valid (even then, had one survivor that was a victim of a serial rapist/murderer and still refused to fully believe that she wasn't in some way *responsible* for what happened to her.). 

The most insidious thing I've learned from my own experiences and being in this field is that there's a trust that is always broken between a survivor and society because we trust, generally speaking, the people around us to NOT sexually abuse us. This sense of trust in society makes survivors feel shame and blame because we are always going over details of what might've happened if we changed this detail or that detail or this phrase or this piece of clothing etc. And I think perpetrators are unfortunately taught that sense of trust too, and, whether we like it or not, oftentimes DONT BELIEVE THAT THEY ARE HURTING SOMEONE. 

I think this is one of the things we need to start addressing in SA/DV spheres - that of perpetrators and perhaps not always condemning people immediately based on their actions IF they are willing to take responsibility and learn from their mistakes. I know it's controversial but there is starting to be discussions around it and I highly recommend reading further. Some personal recommendations are:

Unclenching Our Fists: Abusive Men on the Journey to Nonviolence by Sara Acker
Things We Didn't Talk About When I Was a Girl by Jeannie Vanasco
Know My Name by Chanel Miller (the Brock Turner case) 
No Visible Bruises by Rachel Louise Snyder

By no means a comprehensive list as I've been taking a break from the field for mental health reasons but I truly appreciate someone using a platform like this to talk about the harder conversations regarding sexual assault.

In the extremely rare event that a woman was so sheltered that she actively denied actual rape was rape- well she'd never have been allowed to attend college in the first place, now would she?

author: @bigcrab796
text:
Thanks for this video. I remember reading this account back what feels like a lifetime ago and it still has the same effect of like hitting a wall or slamming on the brakes. It absolutely floored me at the time by forcing me to confront the ambiguous intimacy culture that is the norm. I remember spending time reflecting on past encounters recognizing the similarities and how to fix it. It hasn't been perfect and I've been on both sides of this now, but I'm still trying to be better.

The experience that stands out the most to me now wasn't that period of horror or a guilt of past encounters. What I always remember is a discussion with family--cousins my own age--where we ventured into talking about SA and the then nascent me too movement. I recall bringing up this account about how Aziz's behavior kind of shocked me and was informative about the overall culture, how there was something fundamentally broken. I'll never forget what followed because one of my cousins outright dismissed the encounter and said something to the effect of, "that doesn't count. it wasn't SA." Everyone else agreed with them and I felt stupid, that I didn't actually understand anything about it. Overall, it made me feel that I was just wrong. I doubted my own experiences and feelings.

I'm a bit older now where I can understand I was handling it with the proper care and compassion required. Even still, it took this video to so clearly make sense of what I was trying to grasp back then. Thank you again for this video and all the other work you do.

author: @nojusticenetwork9309
text:
This honestly reminds me of back when I was in the Army. For people not aware, the US army has had a rampant issue with sexual assault amongst personnel for a long time, even when I was enlisted (2011-2018). Back then the Uniform Code of Military Justice outlined (and this could have changed since I was there at this point) that if someone even drank a single bottle/can of alcohol, legally, they could not consent to ANY sexual activity. 

Now for a young 20 something black man who didn't drink alcohol himself, that felt like no issue...until you realized how many soldiers casually or socially drink when off the clock. I got caught with a situation where an associate from my unit and I were flirting with two girls but the one I spoke to had very clearly been drinking and that was a turn off for me so I politely exited the interaction to go and dance, only for the next day to come and I get accused of graping said woman. An investigation was conducted and thankfully the club we were at had cameras showing I was nowhere near the woman when she and her friend and my associate left the club well before I did. The incident scared me so much that too this day, I will not engage with any woman sexually if she's been drinking and doesn't give me enthusiastic verbal consent. IDC how unsexy that might be, I'm not risking prison time because someone wants to play coy or get drunk.

author: @basicbamboo9132
text:
The Aziz situation was the most triggering for me out of any of the public outings of predators because it so exactly mirrored my own experience and the reason I never talked about my experience publicly was because I knew people would act the way that they did the way the NYT OP-ED columnist did. It took me years to understand that what had happened to me was not-consensual and so much after that to even consider that it was not my fault, but I knew that broader society would say that it was. And I was right because that's what they said about Grace.

I remember watching my own hand being moved by his to his penis as attempted to get me to jerk him off, but I was too far gone that each time he would let go it would just shrivel back to my body automatically like a bug. I was not in control of my body at that point. I was watching it happen from somewhere else. When Grace describes how Aziz would move her hand to his penis, I remember what that was like.

I tried to stay away from posts about the situation but when I would get into it with people and say that the same thing happened to me at 13 they would say "that's different, kids can't consent." Then when I told them that my perpetrator was only a year older than me, they wouldn't know what to say.
